title: 108_hr1617
content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit public transportation and efficiency. Eligible projects aim to mitigate traffic congestion, reduce emissions, save energy, and enhance railroad operations. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track and intermodal yard capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving railroad and road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and repairing track structures. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or constructing maintenance or passenger facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20% of project costs funded under this title. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles and loaded rail cars in each State. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad and public road grade crossings in each State. Additionally, 20% of the funds are used for grants for eligible projects of national significance with emphasis on projects with the greatest public benefit. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation ensures that laborers and mechanics on projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. Not less than 10 percent of funds under this Act must go to small businesses owned by disadvantaged individuals. Definitions are based on the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 108. DEFINITIONS. The term "rail miles" refers to route miles, not track miles, and "railroad" includes freight, intercity passenger, and commuter rail transportation as part of the general rail system. "Imposition of tax on railroad locomotives and rolling stock under Sec. 4191." A 5% tax is imposed on specified railroad equipment sales, including locomotives and rolling stock. The tax applies to manufacturers, producers, or importers. Parts and accessories purchased separately are subject to regulations set by the Secretary. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of being placed in service. The tax does not apply to replacement parts. Owners are also liable for the tax. Owners of the trade or business installing parts or accessories are secondarily liable for the tax imposed. A clerical amendment is made to the table of subchapters for chapter 32 of the Code. The amendments for railroad locomotives and rolling stock will be effective on October 1, 2003. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including sections on transportation of persons and property, as well as definitions and special rules. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes a new subchapter on transportation by rail, with sections on the transportation of persons and property. The tax imposed on taxable rail transportation of persons is 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases, to be paid by the person making the payment. The tax imposed on taxable rail transportation of property is 1% of the amount paid for such transportation, applicable only to payments made to a person engaged in the business of transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is to be paid by the person making the payment subject to tax. The tax on taxable rail transportation of property is 1% of the payment made for such transportation, to be paid by the person making the payment subject to tax. If the payment is made outside the United States and the tax is not paid, it must be paid by the person receiving the property in the US or collected by the transporter of the last segment of the transportation. "SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES." For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. "Transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders. The tax must be collected on transportation ordered, and any refunds must deduct the tax due. Payment of the tax is required as per section 4241. Payment of tax under section 4241 must be made at the time of transportation payment. If the tax is not collected through other means, the carrier for the initial US transportation segment must pay the tax. SEC. 203. NATIONAL RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM TRUST FUND. The amendments made by this section will be effective on October 1, 2003. Subchapter A of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section establishing the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, and a portion of customs duties. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund in the Treasury receives taxes under sections 4041 or 4081 related to train fuel, and 10% of royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund are only for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund receives taxes related to train fuel and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund are designated for expenditures under the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
